data.title: Hope Keith Scott and co.are reading!(voices)
data.meta_description: As a fan of vintage era (classic, NO thanks to Michael Eisner applying said term to MODERN Disney toons, no longer is in my ovcablury, eyt anothe r misued...
data.text: As a fan of vintage era (classic, NO thanks to Michael Eisner applying said term to MODERN Disney toons, no longer is in my ovcablury, eyt anothe r misued term-one for another thread) cartoons, I've added these..hope someday I can get the Graham Webb book ANIMATED FILM ENCLYCLOPEDIA (I live and take the bus in the L.A.county area to hollywood,ergo soon I think I'll find it..maybe I can sweettalk my mom into gettin;'it on e-bay..I realize it is at LEAST 125 bucks.... ) Anyway, I offer the following for research,info,and whatnot.BTW another to the list of sources: Jack Kinney (Who worked with epopele who worked everywhere, though never worked to my memory at WB0 and too many others to mention. Here it is,crossposted from my own private offline text file and from several newsgroups --------------------------------- Here is a list of the Warner Bros.golden vintage era voices.This is as far as I know. All alphabetical. A number, of course, were creators of classic Warners animation incl.the great6 Tex Avery. These need no introduction to anyone reading this, and are I'D with * Unless otherwise listed, these thespians had many regular years of the studio (of various lengths.Specific one-timer (or whatever) voices or celeb appearances (Jack Benny) are id'd as such.Sources:ANIMATO (thank you Keith Scott,Graham Webb,and Hames Ware from articles),FUNNYWORLD (thank you Mike Barrier, and again Hames Ware and Graham Webb, in turn their interviews with various personell such as Billy Bletcher, June Foray,Mel Blanc,etc.), and Mark Evanier through his interviews with Ware,Scott,and Webb,and of course onscreen credits and the sheer recongizablity of other voices.(Admittedly some mistkaes might be made here.Feel free to correct) **means returned in later Warner Bros.incartnations (Blanc,Foray,of course)(No one who directed or anything did voices for WB did any voices for them in later incarnations,though Chuck Jones of course at MGM did voices for hsi stuff..if this had been the case with his and other's latter day WB work I;d pout three asterishs!!! SINCE I now have the book, I've added to said list---ID'd in Sogturtle Blue! 1.Elvia Allman (occasional) 2.Eddie "Rochesterr' Anderson (self-caricature,MOUSE THAT JACK BUILT) 3.Tex Avery (legendary director,he did laughs and such for his own toons,1937-1940)* 4.Jim Backus (1947'a A LAD IN HIS LAMP and 1948's WIND BLOWN HARE) 5.Leslie Barringer (1963's BARTHOLOMEW VS WHEEL only) 6.David Barry 7.Eddie Bartell (voice of Beaky,part time,1945) 8.Dick Beals (mostly Ralph Phillips,1953 and 1957) 9.Bea Benadaret 10.Julie Bennett (early 1960s) 11.Jack Benny (self-caricature, THE MOUSE THAT JACK BUILT) 12.Sarah Berner 13.Dick Bickenback (Bing Crosby imitator,SWOONER CROONER) 14.Mel Blanc** 15.Billy Bletcher (villian or other tough sounding voices) 16.Lucille Blias (1958, little girl, A WAGGILY TALE,1958) 17.Tommy Bond (kids's voices,1930s short such as I LOVE TO SINGA,1936) 18.Billy Booth (Wentworth in HONEY'S MONEY,1962) 19.Bernard Brown (music and parttime BUDDY voice,early 1930s) 20.Robert C.Bruce (narrator and occasional onscreen character voices from 1938?-1958) 21.Arthur Q.Bryan (largely Elmer Fudd) 22.Bernard Brownr (voice of Buddy on occasion,1933)* 23.Daws Butler (various supporting roles) 24.Candy Candido (basso voices) 25.Pinto Colvig (best known as Walt Disney'sGoofy,did many such voices,1939-42) 26.Glorya (sic) Curran (1948's BACK ALLEY OPROAR,Deanna Durbin-cat) 27.Ruby Dandridge (COAL BLACK from the self-titled short,1943) 28.Vivian Dandridge (COAL BACK evil Witch) 29.Johnny "Scat" Davis (Johnny Cat-not Kitty Littler ,1938,KATNIP KOLLEGE) 30.John Deering (OLD GLORY's Uncle Sam (1939), and TOM THUMB's dad (1940)) 31.Abe Dinovitch (froggy voices, later 1930s) 32.Dave Dixon (miscredited accidentlaly as Paul, NORMAN NORMAL'S title character,1968) 33.Joe Dougherty (original, 1935-1937 Porky Pig voice, and various others 1934-36) 34.June Foray (females 1952-1966,returned 1978)** 35.Stan Freberg (various supporting males,1944 to 1958)* 36.Paul Frees (occasional supporting characters) 37.Ben Frommer (various characters 1950s-60s) 38.Joanie Gerber (Granny, CORN ON THE COP,1965) 39.Gonzales-Gonzales (various Latino characters,1960s ) 40.Frank Graham (supporting voices,1940s) 41.Roger Green (various support voices from late 50s to mid 60s) 42.Bernice Hansen (cute voices-but NOT SNIFFLES!!,1930s) 43.J.B.Hardaway (brief voice of Bugs Bunny prototype,1938's PORKY'S HARE HUNT) 44.Earle Hodgins (various huckster/barker-type characters,1936-1937) 45.Tom Holland (various latino characters,1955-1962) 46.Cal Howard (writer,voice ofGabby Goatr,1936-1937) 47.Rochelle Hudson (Honey in Bosko series,1930-1933,continued at MGM) 48.Ralph James (narrator,UNMENTIONABLES,and several others) 49.Charles Judels (Italian Gardner, 1937's PORKY's GARDEN) 50.Cy Kendall (the spider in MEATLESS FLYDAY, 1944) 51.Phil Kramer (Brooklynese soudning guys,1930s) 52.Sheldon Leonard (Dodsworth the cat,SOCK-A-DOODLE-DOO banty,1952-53) 53.Jack Lescoulie (specalizing in Jack Benny voices,1935-1944) 54.Mary Livingston (special guest as herself,MOUSE THAT JACK BUILT) 55.Max Maxwell (animator,Bosko) 56.Marvin Miller (various narration) 57.Johnny Murray (occasional voices of Bosko) 58.Victor Moore (hunter in AIN'T THAT DUCKY) 59.Cliff Nazarro (reputedly,Egghead occasionally,narration,known as M.C.Pegnuin in 1938's, PENGUIN PARADE,1938) 60.Dick Nelson (various celeb/other voices,1940s) 61.Frank Nelson (voice of the desk clerk in 1948's DAFFY DUCK SLEPT HERE))** 62.Norman Nesbitt (the narrator of various 1950s shorts,various 50s characters) 63.Pat Patrick (Crow,1951's CORN PLASTERED) 64.GeGe Pearson (Granny,IT'S NICE TO HAVE A MOUSE AROUND THE HOUSE.1964) 65.Richard Peel (narrator in I WAS A TEENAGE THUMB,1962) 66.Lloyd Perryman (the dog in McKimson's WEASEL STOP!) 67.Sylvia Picker (Sniffles, 1943) 68.Tedd Pierce * 69..John Ployardt (Nee John MacLeish;Disney writer,spec.in GOOFY;narration there and at Warner Bros.) 70..Ed Prentiss (narrator, 1959-1962) 71.Thurl Ravenscroft (onscren singing characters,vulture in 1939's PRE-HISTORIC PORKY) 72.Shirley Reed (Petunia Pig,1939) 73.Marian Richman (various UPA-esque ladies in fifties toons) 73.Bill Roberts (Michigan J.Frog,ONE FROGGY EVENING) 73.Kent Rogers (vcarious celeb impressions, Beaky Buzzard in several,1938-1944) 74.Christian Rub (various old men, 1930s) 75.Gaye Seabrooke (voice of SNIFFLES,& similiar characters 1938-1942) 76.Nicolai Shuturov (Giovanni Jones,1949's LONG-HAIRED HARE) 77.Hal Smith (adult cat, MOUSE PLACED KITTEN,1958, and Elmer Fudd, 1960-61) 78.John T.Smith (various supporting voices,1940s-50s incl.CHOW HOUND,HILLBILLY HARE,NO PARKING HARE,etc.) 79.Lionel Stander (named title character in FAGIN'S FREHSMAN, from 1938) 80.N.Paul Stookey (Paul of Peter Pauland Mary,did all of the supporting voices in 1967's NORMAN NORMAL) 81.Larry Storch (Cool Cat,Merlin the Magic mouse (eps 2-4) ,and supporting voices,everybody in FLYING CIRCUS,late 60s) 82.Walter Tetley (title character in 1941's HAUNTED MOUSE) 83.Lloyd Turner (baby turtle,at end of THE SHELL-SHOCKED EGG) 84.Dick Tufeld (occasional narration) 85.Elmore Vincent (1930s cranky old men) 86.Zoot Watson (prince in COAL BLACK,1943) 87.Dave Weber aka Danny Webb (Primary voice of Egghead and various celebs,etc.1936?-1942?) 88.Nancy Wible (various in 1960s)* 89.Don Wilson (special guest as himself, THE MOUSE THAT JACK BUILT,1958) 90.Jane Withers (various; 1988 MICKEY (MOUSE) IS 60, recalled doing soem) 91.Sammy Wolf (the MAD RUSSIA (radio's Bert Gordon) soundin' dog in HARE RIBBIN and possibly other 1940s voices) 92.Gloria Wood (Nelly the Giraffe in NELLY'S FOLLY,1962) 93.Pat Woodell (BUNNY AND CLAUDE series,.Bunny,1968-1969) Special thanks to the voice contributions of mostly long gone Jerry Hausner (brief fill in as Bugs whilst Mel was absent,TV SHOW,1961), and to the SNAFU/HOOK voices, Marjorie Rambeu as the mosquito and BLONDIE star Arthur Lake as Dagwood (Hook of the Navy), and Trustin Howard (Philbert on TV),theme song vocalist Billy Strange for Bunny nd Claude,and also Barbie Cameron.And to the vocal groups & choruses: Mello Men, Blackbirds,Warner Bros.choir, Hall Johnson Choir, and most of all,the Sportsmen. Possible other voices were some MGM-ers:Wally "Screwy Squirrell" Maher, "Rural Riding Hood"'s Imgoene Lynn and Colleen Collins. BTW Sure glaad to edit (as that is the ONLY thing we can do here) and still awaiting my registration to GAC-hope the folks here see this!And thansk Duckdodgess for mentioni9n' m'name! And some others to the list..John A.Ford (singing in Chuck;'s Nelly Folly along i\with Aforementioned Gloria Wood, Ed Prentiss and mel Blanc.) There seems to be some debate as to who's the Levitow UNNTATURAL HISTORY (1959) narrator---Ed Prentiss (Dave mackey) or Byron kane (Webb's book)? Hi Steve~ That's a very good list, it was undoubtedly a great labor of love for you (plus a LOT of typing ). Graham Webb's book does indeed sell for around $125. But his knowledge of cartoon (and old radio) voices is unsurpassed (unless it's by his fellow reseacher Hames Ware, which I doubt), and its all present in Webb's book. His source for the credits for the Disney shorts prior to their mid-'40s adoption of on-screen credits would have to be the Disney archives themselves...But there are oddities and irregularities with these credits just the same... He has T. Hee at Disney too early. Many titles have no storyman listed. And there's almost no mention of Charlie Thorson (5 references for a guy who worked at Disney a couple years, then I believe, at 9 (NINE) other cartoon studios...) However also present in his tome are a lot of unfortunately poor guesses at who wrote/animated/directed on some of the uncredited (or under-credited) classic cartoons... Example: in a fair number of cases he has people animating on MGM cartoons while they were actually still at Walt's!. Likewise he makes Bob Allen the director of Rudy Ising's Oscar winner "The Milky Way" (Ising directed it). He has Michael Sasanoff working on Bob Clampett's two Katz unit MM's (instead of Richard H. Thomas). For whatever reason he fails to list the directors for the 1930-33 Harman-Ising/Warner toons Etc. etc. So like so many cartoon references it is marvelous in some respects...and a creator of confusion as regards other things. BUUUUUT his voice credits in it are superb!! (And intriguingly he ends up correcting information that he and Hames Ware gave to Mike Barrier to write up and publish twenty years earlier, thus Bernice Hansen's last name was actually Hansel, Johnny Murray did all the WB Boskos aside from the first, Cy Kendall did the spider's voice instead of Tex Avery etc.).
